stem: A 54-year-old client with a confirmed large pulmonary embolism (PE) is hypotensive and unresponsive. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Progression to massive (obstructive) PE.
Background: DVT-to-PE transition. Initial treatment was Heparin.
Assessment: BP 72/40. Client is cyanotic around the mouth.
Recommendation: Rescue thrombolytic therapy.

tabs.title: Infusion & Procedure Prep
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent StatusInterpretation
OrderAlteplase (t-PA) 100mg IVThrombolytic
ConsentEmergency impliedLife-threatening
AccessTwo 18G IVsAdequate
Bleeding RiskHistory of major GI bleed 2 yrs agoRelative contraindication

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 72/40, HR 142, RR 36, SpO2 78% on 15L NRM.

conditionOptions.text: Massive Pulmonary Embolism with Obstructive Shock

actionOptions.text: Administer Alteplase (t-PA) IV infusion as prescribed.
Avoid all invasive procedures once infusion starts.
Elevate the legs above the level of the heart.

parameterOptions.text: Level of consciousness and pupil response.

rationale.correct: The client's hypotension (BP 72/40) and hypoxia indicate obstructive shock (Massive PE) (c2). Alteplase (t-PA) (a1) is indicated for hemodynamically unstable PE. Due to bleeding risk, avoid new invasive procedures (a2). Monitor for intracranial hemorrhage (p1) and blood pressure (p2).
clinicalPearls: Thrombolytics dissolve clots; anticoagulants prevent new clots.
Massive PE = SBP < 90 or drop > 40 mmHg from baseline for > 15 mins.
Pulse oximetry can be inaccurate in shock; ABGs are preferred.

questionTrap.trap: Drawing blood gases or starting a Foley after t-PA.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Complete invasive procedures before thrombolytics to avoid bleeding.

mnemonic.title: t-PA Trip
mnemonic.expansion: T-Target clot. P-Punctures avoided. A-Assess Neuro.
